What a tomato might say:
Even without the events of forty years ago, I think man would still be a creature that fears the dark. He doesn't face that fear, he averts his eyes from it and acts as if he doesn't have any memories of his past. But, forty years is both a short time and yet, a long time. Man's fear has withered. And even time itself tries to wither the desire to know the truth. Is it a crime to try and learn the truth? Is it a sin to search for those things which you fear. My purpose in this world is knowledge, and the dissemination of it. And it is I who is to restore the fruits of my labor to the entire world. Fear... It is something vital to us puny creatures. The instant man stop fearing is the instant the species reaches a dead end, only to sink to pitiable lows, only to sit and wait apathetically for extinction. Humans who lose the ability to think become creatures whose existence has no value. Wake up! Don't be afraid of knowledge! Think, you humans who are split into two worlds, unless you want the gulf between humans to expand into oblivion, you must think!

I think we shouldn’t blame wild pigs. Why? Because they do something completely natural for years. As long as we don’t have too much of them and it’s a place there were boars before, let them be pigs. Predators and more meat would be a solution if there are too many.

What’s the difference with humans? We dig out fossil fuels that are deep under the ground and were there for millions of years (about 300 millions of years, some up to 600 millions), even way longer than humans existed (300 000 for a primitive Homo Sapiens). Yeah, it’s of biological origin but nature learned to function without. And now we put it in the atmosphere in just a few hundred years.

Wild pigs are similar to cows, it’s part of a cycle and according to regenerative agriculture, they can even help store CO2 in the soil. Methane CH4 (one carbon “atom of life”, four of hydrogen, also found in water) degrades itself into CO2 (one carbon, two oxygen). Sure, it isn’t the most climate friendly because it takes time to degrade (10 years I heard). But where does the CH4 of cows come from? Grass. And what does grass do? Take CO2 from the atmosphere. If you can graze the fields in the right way, you encourage the grass to store CO2 in the ground. And we want carbon in the soil because it helps to have a better soil.

Boars are helpful because they help avoiding compact soil and they help biodiversity in many ways.

I've been following stories about plant communication and awareness for years. Plants communicate and even cooperate across root systems, have been demonstrated to be susceptible to classical conditioning, and, in instances such as this, are able to respond to harm, which to me just seems eerily similar to a pain response, slowed down to plant-speeds. I'm convinced that the accumulation of results like these are eventually going to challenge our current animal-centric definitions of consciousness.

Feral pigs also destroy fencing costing upwards of $50 million in Texas alone. Those fences have to be repaired which is more unnecessary carbon. They are also causing changes to many species native to the habitats they have invaded. Rattlesnakes are beginning to rattle much less often before striking. Ferals are causing them to evolve because those less likely to rattle are the largest part of the snake population passing their genes along. Ferals eat the snakes that rattle because they can't see good but have excellent hearing. So a rattling snake might as well have a huge blinking neon sign pointing at it that says "food"!.

Vegetarians: "You can't eat meat! You can't eat things that can feel pain!"
Me: "Plants feel pain."
Them: "No, they don't!"
Science: "When a tomato is bring injured, it generates electrical signals to send back to the main plant, which triggers a systemic response to try and avoid the injury, even fighting off the predator hurting it."
Them: "That's not real pain, they don't have a brain to perceive it like we do!"
Me: "Neither do jellyfish, sponges, and many other animals. Can we eat them?"
Them: "No! They're animals!"
Me: "Okay, then, so you're drawing the line at 'animal' for an arbitrary reason, probably rooted in implicit anthropocentric egotism that you don't even realize you have."

http://antimicrobe.org/history/cdc-05-1254.pdf

Key quotes from those sources:
"The H and N antigens of the new H1N1 virus, as well as its behavior toward nonspecific inhibitors, were found to be closely similar to the old H1N1 virus prevalent during the first half of the 1950s. Most of the new H1N1 isolates in eggs were found to be temperature sensitive."

"When antigenic and molecular characterization of this virus showed that both the HA and NA antigens were remarkably similar to those of the 1950s, this finding had profound implications. Where had the virus been that it was relatively unchanged after 20 years? If serially (and cryptically) transmitted in humans, antigenic drift should have led to many changes after 2 decades."

A 2006 paper claimed to have isolated H1N1 influenza virus RNA from ice and melt-water from Siberian lakes that were frequented by migratory birds.
https://journals.asm.org/doi/full/10.1128/JVI.00986-06

A paper highly critical of the 2006 Siberian Lake paper was published in 2008, presenting strong evidence that the reported isolation of influenza RNA from nature was the result of contamination in the laboratory by the standard reference strain of human H1N1 virus (isolated in 1933) that was used as a positive control in that laboratory.
https://journals.asm.org/doi/full/10.1128/JVI.02207-07

The speculation that the 1977 release may have been related to H1N1 vaccine research is supported by the observation that in the initial outbreaks in China, nine of the ten viral isolates expressed “temperature sensitivity” (Kung 1978). Temperature sensitivity normally an uncommon trait, but one that was in the 1970s (and still is) a fundamental trait for making live attenuated influenza vaccines. Temperature sensitivity generally occurs only after a series of substantial laboratory manipulations and selections. The low severity of the 1977 pandemic might be in part due to the temperature sensitivity of the virus, a trait that limits virus replication in pulmonary tissues.
